name: Jerry Seinfeld
blurb: A stand-up comedian and the central character of the show. Obsessed with cleanliness, cereal, and dating.

name: George Costanza
blurb: Jerry's neurotic best friend. Often unemployed, insecure, and full of bad ideas.

name: Elaine Benes
blurb: Jerry's ex-girlfriend and close friend. Independent, witty, and full of iconic dances.

name: Cosmo Kramer
blurb: Jerry's eccentric neighbor. Known for his wild entrances, weird schemes, and big heart.

name: Carol
blurb: Nasal-voiced friend of the group who lives in the Hamptons with her husband Michael. Famous for insisting "You gotta see the baby!"

name: Helen Seinfeld
blurb: Jerry’s doting mother who thinks he’s perfect and can’t imagine why anyone wouldn’t like him. Lives in Florida with her husband Morty and shares his distaste for the Costanzas and Newman.

name: Morty Seinfeld
blurb: Jerry’s stubborn and frugal father who takes pride in inventing the “beltless trench coat” and fiercely defends his son. Retired and living in Florida with Helen, Morty is known for his battles with Velcro and his time as a condo board president.

name: Vanessa
blurb: Jerry’s Season One girlfriend and a lawyer. Though she appears in only two episodes, Vanessa is memorable for their early relationship struggles and a disastrous trip to Vermont.

name: Joel
blurb: Joel Horneck was a childhood friend of Jerry's in "Male Unbonding". Although they were friends as kids, they've grown apart as adults. Jerry decides to end the friendship.

name: Marlene
blurb: Marlene is a seductive yet frustrating woman whom both Jerry and George briefly date in the Seinfeld episode The Ex-Girlfriend, ultimately dumping her due to her endless conversations. She later breaks up with Jerry after seeing his act, saying she can't be with someone she doesn't respect—despite being a cashier herself

name: Uncle Leo
blurb: Uncle Leo is Jerry Seinfeld's uncle (his mother's brother), a bit character who is, even by Seinfeld universe standards, eccentric. He is often loud and somewhat boisterous. He lives in New York city, affording him frequent chances to bump into his nephew.

name: Alton Benes
blurb: Alton is Elaine’s gruff, intimidating father—a Korean War veteran and author of Fair Game—known for his intense demeanor, odd quirks, and tendency to make everyone around him uncomfortable.

name: Donna
blurb: Donna is a woman Jerry dates in "The Phone Message" whose fondness for a "Cotton Dockers" commercial—one Jerry despises—sparks an argument that ultimately ends their relationship.

name: Manny
blurb: Manny is the Spanish-speaking co-manager of Jerry's building in "The Apartment" who helps rent out the vacant unit, unintentionally sparing Jerry from living next to Elaine but leaving him with a loud musician instead.

name: Rava
blurb: Rava is a Finnish writer with a dark outlook on life who appears in "The Statue". After Elaine hires her boyfriend Ray to clean Jerry’s apartment, Jerry accuses Ray of stealing a statue—causing a rift between the couples and ending Rava’s professional relationship with Elaine.

name: Ray
blurb: Ray is Rava's boyfriend and a Columbia University student who appears in "The Statue". Hired to clean Jerry's apartment, Ray impresses Jerry—until Jerry suspects him of stealing a statue, leading to a confrontation that ends with Kramer impersonating a cop to retrieve it

name: Newman
blurb: Newman is Jerry's sworn nemesis and Kramer's eccentric sidekick, known for his sinister greetings and over-the-top schemes. A mailman with a flair for drama and mischief, Newman is both a thorn in Jerry's side and a frequent (if chaotic) partner in crime with Kramer

name: Antonio
blurb: Antonio is a busboy whom George accidentally gets fired in "The Busboy"—a twist of fate that ends up saving Antonio's life when an explosion kills five people at the restaurant shortly after. Grateful, Antonio thanks George, but a random fight with Elaine’s boyfriend leaves him injured, leaving George to care for his cat
